question: Do mice lacking interferon-γ or the interferon-γ receptor show increased resistance to experimental autoimmune myocarditis compared with wild-type mice? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Although myocarditis subsided in wild-type mice after 3 weeks, IFN-gammaR(-/-) mice showed persistent disease.
content.source_2: In BALB/c mice immunized with a peptide derived from cardiac alpha-myosin heavy chain, IFN-γ receptor–deficient animals exhibited only mild myocarditis with negligible mortality, consistent with heightened resistance to the induced autoimmune insult.
content.source_3: These findings indicate that IFN-γ signaling exacerbates autoimmune myocarditis, whereas genetic ablation of IFN-γ or its receptor confers protection by limiting inducible nitric oxide synthase expression and restraining T-cell responses.
